issue.title: Also No Issue, Thanks, But....
issue.body:
Mandatory info for bug reports:

FreeBSD version ( uname -a ): FreeBSD jjstudio 13.2-STABLE FreeBSD 13.2-STABLE GENERIC amd6

CBSD version ( cbsd version ): 13.2.5

Firstly Thank You,

But Also, 

How hard is it to create new linux profiles for jails, specifically ubuntu 22.04 (jammy)?  What's the best place to start to create such a thing and then (hopefully) contribute it back for everyone to use?  

Best,
Joel

release.name: 14.0.0-RELEASE
release.short_description_html:
• jail: improve linux jail: get rootfs in same way as FreeBSD;
  • jail: get rid of centos_7/kfreebsd linux jails profile;
  • jail: added rocky_8, rocky_9 linux jails profile;
  • bhyve: new cloud image: Devuan 5

issue.title: CBSD 13.2.6 does not create mount-point for /usr/home
issue.body:
Hi Oleg

I've just noticed that on FreeBSD 13.2 with CBSD 13.2.6, the /usr/home will not be mounted. It works on other machines with CBSD <13.2.6 and FreeBSD 13.2. And on the affected machine, it used to work until the upgrade to FreeBSD 13.2 and 13.2.6.

The fstab in jails-fstab look fine (have the entry for /usr/home nullfs).
I see an error message when starting the jail (jstart):

`mkdir: /usr/jails/jails/softkeyjail/usr/home: Read-only file system`

Do you have an idea why this could be?

Thanks and best regards,
-Urs

issue.title: CBSD 13.2.6 does not create mount-point for /usr/home
issue.body:
Hi Oleg

I've just noticed that on FreeBSD 13.2 with CBSD 13.2.6, the /usr/home will not be mounted. It works on other machines with CBSD <13.2.6 and FreeBSD 13.2. And on the affected machine, it used to work until the upgrade to FreeBSD 13.2 and 13.2.6.

The fstab in jails-fstab look fine (have the entry for /usr/home nullfs).
I see an error message when starting the jail (jstart):

`mkdir: /usr/jails/jails/softkeyjail/usr/home: Read-only file system`

Do you have an idea why this could be?

Thanks and best regards,
-Urs

comment.body:
Hi,

Thanks for reporting. Its not CBSD regression - some time ago FreeBSD got rid of /usr/home location, CBSD base reflect this changes:

https://cgit.freebsd.org/src/commit/?id=9a6a948128c9e2e39ea728e5f60b8bb82c9c1fca
https://cgit.freebsd.org/src/commit/?id=1186ef86c3e18c7ed7e458260b73794c60aad7a1
https://cgit.freebsd.org/src/commit/?id=8955236a10137a1b645e642baf4eaca9c6460547
[...]

Unfortunately, I did not have time to add automatic migration of `fstab` records  (for example, through sed(1) ).
 Just correct these entries yourself for your containers, edit:

_~cbsd/jails-fstab/<jailname>/fstab_   

and replace '/usr/home' by /home'.

e.g:

```
find ~cbsd/jails-fstab -type fstab | xargs sed -i.bak -e 's:/usr/home:/home:g'
```

PS: If you want to continue to use /usr/home, you can create '/usr/home' in basejail hier:
```
cd ~cbsd/basejail/base_amd64_amd64_**XXX**/usr
mkdir home
```

Please reopen if you need further advice on this issue.

issue.title: CBSD 13.2.6 does not create mount-point for /usr/home
issue.body:
Hi Oleg

I've just noticed that on FreeBSD 13.2 with CBSD 13.2.6, the /usr/home will not be mounted. It works on other machines with CBSD <13.2.6 and FreeBSD 13.2. And on the affected machine, it used to work until the upgrade to FreeBSD 13.2 and 13.2.6.

The fstab in jails-fstab look fine (have the entry for /usr/home nullfs).
I see an error message when starting the jail (jstart):

`mkdir: /usr/jails/jails/softkeyjail/usr/home: Read-only file system`

Do you have an idea why this could be?

Thanks and best regards,
-Urs

issue.title: Also No Issue, Thanks, But....
issue.body:
Mandatory info for bug reports:

FreeBSD version ( uname -a ): FreeBSD jjstudio 13.2-STABLE FreeBSD 13.2-STABLE GENERIC amd6

CBSD version ( cbsd version ): 13.2.5

Firstly Thank You,

But Also, 

How hard is it to create new linux profiles for jails, specifically ubuntu 22.04 (jammy)?  What's the best place to start to create such a thing and then (hopefully) contribute it back for everyone to use?  

Best,
Joel

comment.body:
Hi, Thanks for feedback.

Jails in CBSD described in two places - the first is the `profile` itself (a logical named group of parameters):

1) https://github.com/cbsd/cbsd/blob/develop/etc/defaults/jail-freebsd-ubuntu_jammy.conf

And second, functions to get `rootfs`. Functions to get FreeBSD base/rootfs is `get_base` https://github.com/cbsd/cbsd/blob/v13.2.6/subr/system.subr#L113 , but Linux-based rootfs at the moment it is a separate script, e.g.:

jammy:
https://github.com/cbsd/cbsd/blob/develop/share/FreeBSD-jail-ubuntu-jammy-system-skel/tests/00.check_distribution.sh

bookworm:
https://github.com/cbsd/cbsd/blob/develop/share/FreeBSD-jail-debian-bookworm-system-skel/tests/00.check_distribution.sh

and so on..

I don't really like using bootstrap (besides, it's only for deb/apt-based distros) and in the next version of CBSD I plan to remake it to get the `rootfs` tarball, as it was done for FreeBSD.

ps: any of my experiments and attempts to use Linux containers suggest that it is better to use `bhyve` instead (and cbsd has very powerful tools in the form of cloud profiles support).

release.name: 13.2.6-RELEASE
release.body:
- jails: switch CURRENT/head to 15.0-CURRENT;
- jexec: (work-around)  - disable 'user=XXX' for Linux env;
